TEXT.English: [TAB]A shipyard (or dockyard) is a place where ships and boats are built and repaired. Any civilization that is interested in producing effective naval power will need to construct shipyards. For obvious reasons, shipyards must be built by the sea (or on large rivers) to allow ships to enter and leave. Shipyards require both a good natural harbor and a great deal of organization in order to ensure the efficient production of ships. In fact, ships were among the first items to be built using factory-style organization.
TEXT.French: Un chantier naval est un endroit où les navires et les bateaux sont construits et réparés. N'importe quelle civilisation qui désire produire une puissance navale efficace aura besoin de construire des chantiers navals. Pour des raisons évidentes, les chantiers navals doivent être construits au bord de la mer (ou sur de grands fleuves) pour permettre aux navires d'entrer et partir. Les chantiers navals exigent à la fois un bon port naturel et beaucoup d'organisation pour garantir la production efficiente de navires. En fait, les navires étaient parmi les premiers articles à être construits selon des méthodes industrielles.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In einer Werft werden Boote und Schiffe gebaut und repariert. Jede Zivilisation, die sich eine gut funktionierende Flotte aufbauen möchte, muss Werften bauen. Logischerweise müssen sie in Küstenstädten (oder an großen Flüssen gelegenen Städten) errichtet werden, damit die Schiffen ein- und ausfahren können. Eine Werft benötigt einen guten natürlichen Hafen und eine gute Organisation, um eine effiziente Schiffsproduktion zu gewährleisten. Demzufolge waren Schiffe auch die ersten Dinge, die in Fabrik-ähnlicher Art und Weise hergestellt wurden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il Cantiere Navale è il posto dove navi e barche vengono costruite e riparate. Qualsiasi civiltà che è interessata a creare un'efficente potenza navale deve costruire Cantieri Navali. Per ovvie ragioni, i Cantieri Navali devono essere costruiti vicino al mare (o su grandi fiumi) per permettere alle navi di entrare e uscire. I Cantieri Navali richiedono sia un buon porto naturale che una grande organizzazione per assicurare un'efficente produzione di imbarcazioni. Infatti, le imbarcazioni furono tra le prime cose ad essere costruite utilizzando un'organizzazione industriale.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un Astillero es un lugar donde los barcos y botes son construidos y reparados. Cuanquier civilización que esté interesada en producir un poder naval decente necesitará construir astilleros. Por razones obvias, los astilleros deben construirse en el mar (o en ríos grandes) para permitir a los barcos entrar y salir. Los Astilleros requieren tanto un buen puerto natural como una gran organización con el objeto de asegurar la producción eficiente de las naves. De hecho, los barcos fueron de los primeros instrumentos en ser construidos utilizando un estilo de organización industrial.

TEXT.English: In the frozen tundra of the Age of Ice people rarely had to worry about preserving their meat for the future, for the incredibly low temperatures could keep most foodstuffs in stasis for an indefinite period. In the rare cases where hunters caught more meat than they could carry on their backs, they usually dug a hole a few feet deep and deposited it there, where the cold kept it fresh and several heavy boulders prevented scavengers. Once they lost this natural refrigeration in the Age of Rebirth though, they had to relearn how to properly treat meat against rot, generally by drying and smoking it as it hung from the rafters of a special smokehouse.

In den seltenen Fällen, in denen die Jäger mehr Fleisch erbeuteten als sie tragen konnten, gruben sie einfach ein wenige Fuß tiefes Loch in die Erde und legten es dorthinein, sodass die Kälte es frisch hielt und ein paar schwere Steine obenauf Aasfresser abhielten. Sobald sie diese Tiefkühlung mit Beginn des Zeitalters der Wiedergeburt verloren, mussten sie erneut lernen, wie man Fleisch vor Verwesung bewahrt, normalerweise durch Trocknen und Räuchern, während es von den Sparren einer speziell dafür errichteten Räucherei herabhängt.
TEXT.Italian: Nella tundra congelata dell'Era del Ghiaccio le persone raramente si dovevano preoccupare di preservare i pasti per il futuro, perché le temperature incredibilmente basse potevano mantenere la maggior parte dei cibi in stasi per un periodo di tempo indeffinito. Nei rari casi in cui i cacciatori avevano più carne di quanta ne potevano portare, scavavano un buco profondo qualche centimetro e la depositavano li, dove il freddo la avrebbe mantenuta fresca e dei massi ne impedivano il saccheggio. Quando perserò questa refrigerazione naturale nell'Era della Rinascita, dovetterò ri-imparare a trattare la carne contro la decomposizione, generalmente essicandola e affumicandola mentre era sospesa dal soffitto di un affumicatoio.

TEXT.English: [TAB]There are hundreds of different kinds of taverns across Erebus, some quiet and comfortable, others violent and dangerous. But the most interesting lies in the sewers beneath Alexandria and is called "The Pit." It only opens at night, when the curfew keeps the honorable inside their homes and those with more exotic tastes sneak to and from the labyrinth of sewer passages to get to the Pit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Within everyone wears masks, the common folk wear black hoods while the rich often sport lavish demon masks set with valuable stones and gold. Masks set with fake gems and painted to look like valuable metals allow a commoner to masquerade as a noble, and a simple black burlap sack with eyeholes allows a high priest to find lurid pleasures without being noticed.[PARAGRAPH:1]There are various forms of debauchery practiced in the Pit, but the most renown is the Chorus of Hell. Within the deepest hell there are wastes filled with the souls of those that committed suicide. These souls are gathered by demons and forced to lament eternally as it pleases the lord of despair. The Chorus of Hell is a single man who is able to channel this music. As he stands on the Pit's sunken stage sounds too horrific and beautiful for a single voice pour through him into the room. The effect is entrancing and those that hear it find it haunts them for weeks and months afterwards. More than a few people have committed suicide themselves after hearing the song. The truly depraved never miss a performance.

Aber die wohl interessanteste Taverne ist der Kanalisation unter Alexandria und trägt den Namen "Die Grube". Sie öffnet nur nachts, wenn die Sperrstunde das ehrbare Leute in ihren Häusern halt und solche mit exotischeren Vorlieben sich durch das Labyrinth der Abwasserkanäle schleichen um zur Grube zu gelangen.[PARAGRAPH:1]In der Grube tragen alle Masken, das gewöhnliche Volk schwarze Kapuzen, die Reichen oftmals prunkvolle Dämonenmasken, geschmückt mit Edelsteinen und Gold. Masken mit falschen Juwelen und Bemalungen, die wertvolle Metalle nachahmen, erlauben es den Gewöhnlichen sich als Adelige auszugeben, während ein einfacher schwarzer Leinensack mit Augenlöchern es dem Hohepriester ermöglicht unerkannt seinen absonderlichen Gelüsten nachzugehen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Verschiedenartigste Ausschweifungen finden in der Grube statt, aber die bekannteste ist der Chor der Hölle. Diese Seelen werden von Dämonen aufgesammelt und dazu gezwungen auf ewig zu klagen, ganz wie es dem Fürst der Verzweiflung gefällt. Der Chor der Hölle ist ein einzelner Mann, der in der Lage ist diese Musik zu kanalisieren. Während er auf der eingelassenen Bühne der Grube steht, schallen Töne, zu entsetzlich und wunderschön für eine einzelne Stimme, durch ihn in den Raum. Der Klang hat einen fesselnden Effekt auf die Hörer und verfolgt sie oft noch für Wochen und Monate - und so manche begingen, nachdem sie das Lied hörten, selber Selbstmord. Die wahrhaft Verkommenen verpassen niemals einen Auftritt.

Ma la più interessante sta nelle fogne di Alexandria e si chiama "La Fossa". Apre solo di notte, quando il coprifuoco mantiene le persone onorevoli a casa e quelli con gusti più esotici entrano ed escono furtivamente dal labirinto di passaggi fognari per arrivare alla Fossa.[PARAGRAPH:1]All'interno tutti indossano maschere, la gente comune usa cappucci neri mentre i ricchi spesso fanno sfoggio di sontuose maschere di demoni con gemme preziose e oro. Maschere con finte pietre preziose e colorate in modo da sembrare di metalli preziosi permettono a un cittadino comune di passare per un nobile, e un semplice sacco di tela nero con i buchi per gli occhi permette ad un alto prete di trovare piaceri lussuriosi senza essere notato.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ci sono varie forme di depravazione praticate nella Fossa, ma la più famose è il Coro dell'Inferno. All'interno dell'inferno più profondo ci sono innumerevoli anime di coloro che si sono suicidati. Queste anime sono riunite dai demoni e costrette a lamentarsi per l'eternità per compiacere il signore della disperazione. Il Coro dell'Inferno è un solo uomo che è capace di incanalare questa musica. Mentre si trova sul palco sommerso della Fossa suoni troppo orribili e magnifici per una singola voce fuoriescono da lui in tutta la stanza. L'effetto è incantevole e coloro che lo sentono scoprono che li perseguita per settimane e mesi. Più di qualche persona si è suicidata dopo aver sentito la canzone. I veri depravati non si perdono mai uno spettacolo.

TEXT.English: Increases trade as it draws travelers and their money into your city. On the negative side, a Tavern does bring some lawlessness into your city, increasing the maintenance. Because of this, it is best used in core financial cities and not in remote cities that are already paying high maintenance costs.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Augmente le commerce en attirant des voyageurs et leur argent dans votre ville. Le côté négatif est qu'une Taverne amène de la délinquance dans votre ville, augmentant le coût d'entretien. A cause de cela, elle est mieux utilisée en étant construite dans les villes du noyau financier et pas dans les villes lointaines qui doivent déjà payer un fort coût de maintenance.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Gewährt +1 Handelsweg und 25% mehr Handelsumsatz, da die Reisenden und ihr Geld in die Stadt gelockt werden. Eine größere Anzahl an Abenteurern und Söldner reduziert die Kosten für Einheitenrekrutierung um 10%. Negatives: Eine Taverne bringt einige Gesetzes untreue in deine Stadt, die Versorgungskosten steigen um 10%. Deshalb sollte man es nur in wirtschaftsreichen Städten benutzen und nicht in Randstädten, welche schon hohe Versorgungskosten zahlen müssen.

A causa di ciò, è meglio usarla nelle città finanziarie primarie evitando le città remote che già pagano un alto costo di mantenimento.

Por esto, es mejor usarla en ciudades núcleo de finanzasy no en ciudades remotas que ya están costando un coste alto de mantenimiento.

TEXT.English: [TAB]It lay at the heart of the temple, a strange amalgam of pearl and coral, a thing touched by the power of the Overlords. A living thing, it was constantly rippling, the way a stormy sea ripples, and we could hear its ripples in our minds, the music of distant waves. From the moment when I saw it, I knew I shouldn't have come: but some other part of me rejoiced, drawn to its lure like a moth is drawn to a flame.[PARAGRAPH:1]The priests held gatherings at the beginning of each week, open for all. Newcomers would need to be taken to the chamber with the coral, while the rest of us knew the way, even the ones who'd only been there once before. From the moment we stepped to the surroundings of the temple, we could feel the faint whisper of the waves, guiding us towards the temple's heart. We approached and outsiders always felt unnerved, unable to tell why, only subconsciously noticing the slight wave in our shoulders, our bodies picking up the rhythm of the chamber.[PARAGRAPH:1]We would gather around the coral and dance and laugh and celebrate, seeing strange visions of a vast kingdom, now buried under the sea. As the hours passed, the dance would grow faster and faster and the music would grow louder and louder. Only that the music was only in our heads, an intoxicating storm that was sweeter than any nectar. We were drunk on the coral, ready to do anything, and more than one child was conceived with a total stranger on those nights. Sometimes the priests would join into our celebration, but most of the time they would just stand aside, watching, waiting.[PARAGRAPH:1]The nights always left me exhausted, my body in pain after I had neglected its limits. I worried about going too far-every year, there were some who'd die of the exhaustion-and occasionally I tried to stay away. But the music of the waves would always haunt me in my dreams, a faint tune stuck in my head, infuriatingly just a little too quiet to be heard. And the visions that I would have after a good temple night! I was a poet and an artist, and nothing could leave me more inspired, nothing could compare to the poems I would compose after listening to the corals. Was it more for the sake of myself or my art, I'm not sure, but I always found myself returning after a while.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the priestesses seemed to take a special interest in me when I returned after an exceptionally long absence. She never said anything, but I could feel her eyes on me when I danced, thoughtful. I would catch the occasional whisper as she discussed something with the others, though I never made out any exact words.[PARAGRAPH:1]After several such nights, something in the music crazed me in a way it had never crazed me before. My dance was wild, my visions feverish, my body screaming in ever-increasing agony as the night progressed. I could see the others growing tired and leaving, but I could not bring myself to stop, could not leave the coral that suddenly seemed to only be singing to me. I could see in the dance of the others that they did not hear the same tune as I did: their rhythm and their steps were all wrong. So when they left I ignored them, knowing that they were deaf to the true music I was hearing.[PARAGRAPH:1]Then, when I was alone save for her, the priestess came and joined my dance. Her dance was perfect, in complete harmony with the waves, and I watched her, enthralled by the beauty I suddenly saw in her. I sought to imitate her elegance, but my own clumsiness was apparent to me-but she did not seem to mind, for she only smiled. She took my hand, and continuing to smile, she led me away from the coral, to a part of the temple I had never been in before. I paid no heed to my surroundings-the ecstasy of the coral was nothing compared to the pleasure of her attention, every muscle in my body shivering each time she looked at me. I was lost in her, the details of her body being like a vast, deep valley I could never climb out of.[PARAGRAPH:1]It never crossed my mind to protest as we came to the pool and she pushed me into the water. I felt something grabbing my arms and legs and pulling me down, but the priestess smiled at me, and her happiness was all that I cared for. I opened my mouth to sing a song of praise for her, and it was only then that I realized I was underwater, water filling my mouth and my lungs. For a brief moment, panic filled me and broke the spell-I screamed, and the priestess only smiled in return.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The priestess still smiles at me, in a strange amused way that I have a hard time deciphering. It has become hard to think at things, after the drowning. It is much easier to kill, those that the priestess tells me to kill.[PARAGRAPH:1]For a moment, I thought I felt a distant memory when I crushed the skull of the first people the priestess told me to slay. She must have seen my confusion, for she laughed in her angelic voice. With a happy gleam in her eye, she told me that the corpses at my feet were those of my wife and children. I looked at her and the bodies, and there was another momentary feeling of recalling something, but the words bore no meaning to me. I looked at the corpses and shrugged, and we left, her joy echoing in my ears.[PARAGRAPH:1]I'm the bodyguard of the priestess, now. For as long as she is happy with me, the music of the waves will never leave me, and that is all that matters.

I sought to imitate her elegance, but my own clumsiness was apparent to me-but she did not seem to mind, for she only smiled. She took my hand, and continuing to smile, she led me away from the coral, to a part of the temple I had never been in before. I paid no heed to my surroundings-the ecstasy of the coral was nothing compared to the pleasure of her attention, every muscle in my body shivering each time she looked at me. I was lost in her, the details of her body being like a vast, deep valley I could never climb out of.[PARAGRAPH:1]It never crossed my mind to protest as we came to the pool and she pushed me into the water. I felt something grabbing my arms and legs and pulling me down, but the priestess smiled at me, and her happiness was all that I cared for. I opened my mouth to sing a song of praise for her, and it was only then that I realized I was underwater, water filling my mouth and my lungs. For a brief moment, panic filled me and broke the spell-I screamed, and the priestess only smiled in return.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The priestess still smiles at me, in a strange amused way that I have a hard time deciphering. It has become hard to think at things, after the drowning. It is much easier to kill, those that the priestess tells me to kill.[PARAGRAPH:1]For a moment, I thought I felt a distant memory when I crushed the skull of the first people the priestess told me to slay. She must have seen my confusion, for she laughed in her angelic voice. With a happy gleam in her eye, she told me that the corpses at my feet were those of my wife and children. I looked at her and the bodies, and there was another momentary feeling of recalling something, but the words bore no meaning to me. I looked at the corpses and shrugged, and we left, her joy echoing in my ears.[PARAGRAPH:1]I'm the bodyguard of the priestess, now. For as long as she is happy with me, the music of the waves will never leave me, and that is all that matters.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Im Herzen des Tempels lag es, eine absonderliche Mischung aus Perle und Koralle, ein Ding, berührt von den Kräften der Tiefe. Ein lebendes Ding, ein Ding das sich kräuselt, wie eine sturmgepeitschte See sich kräuselt. Wir konnten sein Plätschern in unseren Gedanken hören, so wie die Musik weit entfernter Wellen. Von dem Moment an, in dem ich es sah, wusste ich, ich hätte nicht kommen sollen: Aber ein anderer Teil von mir freute sich, angezogen von einem Köder, so wie eine Motte vom Feuer angezogen wird.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Priester halten zu Beginn jeder Woche Versammlungen ab, offen für jedermann. Neulinge müssen erst in die Kammer mit der Koralle geführt werden. Alle anderen kennen den Weg bereits, selbst wenn sie erst ein einziges Mal zuvor dort waren. Von dem Moment an, in dem wir uns dem Tempel näherten, konnten wir es fühlen, das Ferne Wispern der Wellen, das uns zum Herz des Tempels geleitete. Wir näherten uns und Außenseiter waren dann immer sehr nervös, auch wenn sie nie sagen konnten wieso. Nur unterbewusst nahmen wir die leichte Schwingung in unseren Schultern wahr, wenn unsere Körper in den Rythmus der Wellen verfielen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Wir würden uns um die Koralle versammeln und tanzen und lachen und feiern, seltsame Visionen eines gewaltigen Königreiches empfangen, das nun unter der See begraben liegt. So wie die Stunden vergehen werden, so würde unser Tanz immer schneller und schneller, die Musik immer lauter und lauter werden. Nur das die Musik nur in unseren Köpfen war, ein berauschender Sturm, süßer als jeder Nektar. Wir waren berauscht von der Koralle, bereit, einfach alles zu tun, und in diesen Nächten wurde mehr als nur ein Kind von völlig Fremden gezeugt. Manchmal nahmen die Priester an unseren Feiern teil, aber meist stehen sie nur abseits, beobachtend, wartend.[PARAGRAPH:1]Diese Nächte ließen mich immer völlig ermattet zurück, mit einem Körper aus purem Schmerz, nachdem ich ihn an seine Grenzen geführt hatte. Ich machte mir Sorgen zu weit zu gehen - jedes Jahr stirbt jemand an völliger Erschöpfung - und gelegentlich versuchte ich den Feiern fern zu bleiben. Aber die Musik der Wellen würde mich dann ewig in meinen Träumen verfolgen, eine leise in meinem Kopf feststeckende Melodie, gerade leise genug um nicht gehört zu werden, so dass es einen zur Verzweiflung treibt. Und die Visionen erst, die ich nach einer berauschenden Tempelnacht haben würde! Ich war ein Dichter und ein Künstler und nichts könnte mich mehr inspiriert haben, nichts wäre mit den Gedichten vergleichbar gewesen, die ich geschrieben hätte, wenn ich der Musik der Koralle gelauscht hätte. Ob es nun mehr wegen mir oder doch eher wegen meiner Kunst war, ich bin mir nicht sicher, aber auf jeden Fall bin ich, nach einiger Zeit, immer wieder zurückgekehrt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eine der Priesterinnen schien ein besonderes Interesse an mir zu haben, als ich nach einer überaus langen Abwesenheit wieder zurück kam. Sie sagte nie etwas, aber ich spürte ihre nachdenklichen Blicke auf mir, wenn ich tanzte. Ich konnte ein gelegentliches Flüstern aufschnappen, wenn sie etwas mit den anderen diskutierte, aber ich konnte nie etwas genaues verstehen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach ein paar solcher Nächte machte mich irgendetwas in der Musik auf eine Art und Weise verrückt, wie es nie zuvor geschehen war. Mein Tanz war wild, meine Visionen fieberartig, mein Körper schrie vor immer größer werdender Agonie, je länger die Nacht dauerte. Ich konnte sehen, wie die anderen müde wurden und gingen, aber ich konnte mich selbst nicht stoppen, ich konnte die Koralle nicht verlassen, die anscheinend nur noch für mich zu singen schien. Ich konnte am Tanz der anderen erkennen, dass sie nicht die gleiche Melodie zu hören schienen wie ich: Ihr Rhythmus und ihre Bewegungen waren alle falsch. Also ignorierte ich sie als sie gingen, wohl wissend, dass sie für die wahre Musik taub waren, wie lediglich ich sie hören konnte[PARAGRAPH:1]Dann, als ich alleine war, kam die Priesterin und nahm an meinem Tanz teil. Ihr Tanz war perfekt, in kompletter Harmonie mit den Wellen, und ich sah ihr zu, begeistert von der Schönheit, die ich plötzlich in ihr sah. Ich versuchte ihre Eleganz zu imitieren, aber meine eigene Unbeholfenheit war offensichtlich - aber das schien sie nicht zu stören, denn sie lächelte einfach nur. Sie nahm meine Hand und während sie weiter lächelte führte sie mich weg von der Koralle und in einen Teil des Tempels, in dem ich nie zuvor gewesen war. Ich schenke meiner Umgebung keine Beachtung - die Ekstase der Koralle war nichts im Vergleich zu dem Vergnügen ihrer Aufmerksamkeit, jede Faser meines Körpers zitterte, wenn sie mich ansah. Ich war ihr verfallen, jedes Detail ihres Kröpers war wie ein tiefes Tal, aus dem ich niemals würde herausklettern können.[PARAGRAPH:1]Es kam mir nicht in den Sinn zu protestieren, als wir das Becken erreichten und sie mich ins Wasser schob. Ich fühlte, wie etwas meine Arme und Beine ergriff und mich in die Tiefe zog, aber die Priesterin lächelte mich an und dass sie glücklich war, war alles, was für mich zählte. Ich öffnete meinen Mund um ihr ein Loblied zu singen und erst da realisierte ich, dass ich unter Wasser war, erst als Wasser meinen Mund und meine Lunge zu füllen begann. Für einen kurzen Moment geriet ich in Panik und der Zauber wurde gebrochen - ich schrie, doch die Priesterin lächelte nur als Antwort.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]------[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Die Priesterin lächelt mir immer noch zu, auf eine seltsame, schwer zu deutende Art und Weise amüsiert. Es ist schwierig geworden über Dinge nachzudenken, nachdem ich ertränkt worden bin. Es ist viel einfacher zu töten, diejenigen die die Priesterin mir aufträgt zu töten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Für einen Moment dachte ich, eine entfernte Erinnerung zu spüren, als ich die Schädel der ersten Personen zermalmte, die die Priesterin mir aufgetragen hatte zu erschlagen. Sie muss meine Verwirrung bemerkt haben, denn sie lachte mit ihrer engelhaften Stimme. Mit einem zufriedenen Funkeln in ihren Augen sagte sie mir, dass die Körper zu meinen Füßen die meiner Frau und meiner Kinder wären. Ich sah abwechselnd sie und die Körper an und da war ein weiteres Mal das Gefühl, als würde eine Erinnerung zurück kommen, aber das hatte keine Bedeutung mehr für mich. Ich betrachtete die Körper und zuckte mit den Schultern. Wir gingen fort und ihre Entzückung war ein Echo in meinen Ohren.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nun bin ich der Beschützer der Priesterin. Und so lange sie zufrieden mit mir ist, so lange wird die Musik der Wellen mich nicht verlassen. Und das ist alles was zählt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Giace al centro del tempio, una strana amalgama di perle e coralli, una cosa toccata dal potere dei Padroni. Una cosa vivente, era costantemente increspata, come un mare in tempesta, e noi potevamo ssentire le increspature nella nnosta mente, la musica di onde distanti. Dal momento in cui la vidi, seppi che non saremo dovuti venire: ma qualche altra parte di me si rallegrava, attratta dal suo richiamo come una falena è attirata da una fiamma.[PARAGRAPH:1]I preti ospitano riunioni all'inizio di ogni settimana, aperte a tutti. I nuovi arrivati devono essere portati nella stanza col corallo, mentre gli altri di noi conoscono già la strada, persino quelli che sono stati qui solo una volta. Nel momento che entriamo nei dinotrni del tempio, possiamo sentire il debole sussurro delle onde, guidarci verso il cuore del tempio. Ci avviciniamo e gli stanieri sono sempre nervosi, incapaci di capire perché, notando solamente inconsciamente le onde nelle nostre spalle, i nostri corpi adattandosi al ritmo della camera.[PARAGRAPH:1]Noi ci riuniamo attorno al corallo e danziamo e ridiamo e celebriamo, avendo visioni di ampi regni, ora sepolti sotto il mare. Con il passare delle ore, la danza aumenta di velocità e la musica diventa sempre più alta. Solo che la musica era sono nelle nostre teste, una tempesta inebriante che era più dolce di qualsiasi nettare. Eravamo ubriachi del corallo, pronti a fare qualsiasi cosa, e più di un bambino è stato concepito con perfetti sconosciuti in quelle notti. A volte i preti si uniscono alle noistre celebrazioni, ma la maggior parte delle volte stanno da parte, osservando, aspettando.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quelle notti mi lasciano sempre esausto, il mio corpo dolorante dopo che ho trascurato i suoi limiti. Ho temuto di essere andato oltre, ogni anno c'è qualcuno che muore dallo sfinimento, e occasionalmente ho provato a stare lontano. Ma la musica delle ondo mi perseguita sempre nei miei sogni, una debole nota fissa nella mia testa, esasperatamente troppo silenziosa per essere sentita. E le visioni che ho dopo una bella notte al tempio! Ero un poeta e un artista, e nulla può lasciarmi più ispirato, nulla può essere paragonato alle poesi che compongo dopo aver ascoltato i coralli. Era più per la mia arte o per me stesso, non ne sono certo, ma io ci torno sempre dopo un pò.[PARAGRAPH:1]Una delle sacerdotesse sembra aver sviluppato uno speciale interesse in me quando sono tornato da un'incredibile lunga assenza. Lei non ha mai detto niente, ma io potevo sentire i suoi occhi su di me quando danzavo, riflettendo. Io sentivo qualche occasionale sussurro mentre lei discuteva di qualcosa con gli altri, sebbene non riuscivo a capire le esatte parole.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dopo diverse notti, qualcosa nella musica mi fece impazzire come mai prima. La mia danza era slevaggia, le mie visioni febbrili, il mio corpo urlava in un'agonia sempre più grande man mano che la notte avanzava. Potevo vedere gli altri stancarsi e andarsene, ma io non riuscivo a fermarmi, non potevo lasciare il corallo che improvvisamente sembrava stesse cantando solo a me. Potevo vedere nella danza degli altri che non sentivano le mie stesse note: il loro ritmo e i loro passi erano tutti sbagliati. Quindi quando se ne andarono io li ignorai, sapendo che loro erano sordi alla vera musica che io stavo sentendo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Poi, quando ero da solo con lei, la sacerdotessa si unì alla mia danza. Danzava in maniera perfetta, in completa armonia con le onde, e io la guardai, incantato dalla bellezza improvvisa che vedevo in lei. Tentai di imitare la sua eleganza, ma la mia goffagine mi era apparente, ma a lei non sembrava importare, perché lei sorrideva solamente. Mi prese la mano e, continuando a sorridere, mi portò lontano dal corallo, in una parte del tempio in cui non sono mai stato prima. Non mi interessai a dove mi trovavo, l'estasi del corallo era niente in confronto al piacere della sua attenzione, ogni muscolo del mio corpo tremava quando lei mi guardava. Mi ero perso in lei, i dettagli del suo corpo erano come una profonda vallata da cui non sarei mai riuscito ad uscire.[PARAGRAPH:1]Non mi passo mai per la testa di protestare mentre ci avvicinavamo alla piscina e mi butto in acqua. Sentii qualcosa afferarmi braccia e gambe e trascinarmi giu, ma la sacerdotessa mi sorrise, e la sua felicità era l'unica cosa che mi importava. Aprii la bocca per cantare una canzone per lodarla, ed fu solo allora che realizai di essere sott'acqua, con l'acqua che mi riempiva la bocca e i polmoni. Per un breve momento, il panico mi sommerse e spezzò la magia, urlai,e la sacerdotessa sorrise in risposta.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]La sacerdotessa continuava a sorridermi,in un modo stranamente divertito per me difficile da decifrare. È diventato difficile pensare alle cose, dopo l'affogamento. È molto più facile uccidere, coloro che la sacerdotessa mi dice di uccidere.[PARAGRAPH:1]Per un momento, ho pensato di di provare un distante ricordo quando ho spaccato il cranio della prima persona che la sacerdotessa mi ha detto di uccidere. Deve aver visto la mia confusione, perché lei rise con la sua voce angelica. Con un bagliore felice negli occhi, mi disse che i corpi ai miei piedi erano quelli di mia moglie e mio figlio. Io la guardai e poi guardai i corpi, e ci un fu un'altro momentaneo sentimento o richiamo di qualcosa, ma le parole non avevano alcun significato per me. Guardai ai corpi e scossi le spalle, e ce ne andammo, la sua gioia facendo l'eco nelle mie orecchie.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sono la guardia del corpo della sacerdotessa, ora. Fino a quando lei sarà felice di me, la musica delle onde non mi abbandonerà mai, e questo è tutto ciò che mi importa.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]It lay at the heart of the temple, a strange amalgam of pearl and coral, a thing touched by the power of the Overlords. A living thing, it was constantly rippling, the way a stormy sea ripples, and we could hear its ripples in our minds, the music of distant waves. From the moment when I saw it, I knew I shouldn't have come: but some other part of me rejoiced, drawn to its lure like a moth is drawn to a flame.[PARAGRAPH:1]The priests held gatherings at the beginning of each week, open for all. Newcomers would need to be taken to the chamber with the coral, while the rest of us knew the way, even the ones who'd only been there once before. From the moment we stepped to the surroundings of the temple, we could feel the faint whisper of the waves, guiding us towards the temple's heart. We approached and outsiders always felt unnerved, unable to tell why, only subconsciously noticing the slight wave in our shoulders, our bodies picking up the rhythm of the chamber.[PARAGRAPH:1]We would gather around the coral and dance and laugh and celebrate, seeing strange visions of a vast kingdom, now buried under the sea. As the hours passed, the dance would grow faster and faster and the music would grow louder and louder. Only that the music was only in our heads, an intoxicating storm that was sweeter than any nectar. We were drunk on the coral, ready to do anything, and more than one child was conceived with a total stranger on those nights. Sometimes the priests would join into our celebration, but most of the time they would just stand aside, watching, waiting.[PARAGRAPH:1]The nights always left me exhausted, my body in pain after I had neglected its limits. I worried about going too far-every year, there were some who'd die of the exhaustion-and occasionally I tried to stay away. But the music of the waves would always haunt me in my dreams, a faint tune stuck in my head, infuriatingly just a little too quiet to be heard. And the visions that I would have after a good temple night! I was a poet and an artist, and nothing could leave me more inspired, nothing could compare to the poems I would compose after listening to the corals. Was it more for the sake of myself or my art, I'm not sure, but I always found myself returning after a while.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the priestesses seemed to take a special interest in me when I returned after an exceptionally long absence. She never said anything, but I could feel her eyes on me when I danced, thoughtful. I would catch the occasional whisper as she discussed something with the others, though I never made out any exact words.[PARAGRAPH:1]After several such nights, something in the music crazed me in a way it had never crazed me before. My dance was wild, my visions feverish, my body screaming in ever-increasing agony as the night progressed. I could see the others growing tired and leaving, but I could not bring myself to stop, could not leave the coral that suddenly seemed to only be singing to me. I could see in the dance of the others that they did not hear the same tune as I did: their rhythm and their steps were all wrong. So when they left I ignored them, knowing that they were deaf to the true music I was hearing.[PARAGRAPH:1]Then, when I was alone save for her, the priestess came and joined my dance. Her dance was perfect, in complete harmony with the waves, and I watched her, enthralled by the beauty I suddenly saw in her. I sought to imitate her elegance, but my own clumsiness was apparent to me-but she did not seem to mind, for she only smiled. She took my hand, and continuing to smile, she led me away from the coral, to a part of the temple I had never been in before. I paid no heed to my surroundings-the ecstasy of the coral was nothing compared to the pleasure of her attention, every muscle in my body shivering each time she looked at me. I was lost in her, the details of her body being like a vast, deep valley I could never climb out of.[PARAGRAPH:1]It never crossed my mind to protest as we came to the pool and she pushed me into the water. I felt something grabbing my arms and legs and pulling me down, but the priestess smiled at me, and her happiness was all that I cared for. I opened my mouth to sing a song of praise for her, and it was only then that I realized I was underwater, water filling my mouth and my lungs. For a brief moment, panic filled me and broke the spell-I screamed, and the priestess only smiled in return.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The priestess still smiles at me, in a strange amused way that I have a hard time deciphering. It has become hard to think at things, after the drowning. It is much easier to kill, those that the priestess tells me to kill.[PARAGRAPH:1]For a moment, I thought I felt a distant memory when I crushed the skull of the first people the priestess told me to slay. She must have seen my confusion, for she laughed in her angelic voice. With a happy gleam in her eye, she told me that the corpses at my feet were those of my wife and children. I looked at her and the bodies, and there was another momentary feeling of recalling something, but the words bore no meaning to me. I looked at the corpses and shrugged, and we left, her joy echoing in my ears.[PARAGRAPH:1]I'm the bodyguard of the priestess, now. For as long as she is happy with me, the music of the waves will never leave me, and that is all that matters.

TEXT.English: "There has been a lot said about the sacredness of our land which is our body; and the values of our culture which is our soul; but water is the blood of our tribes, and if its life-giving flow is stopped, or it is polluted, all else will die and the many thousands of years of our communal existence will come to an end." [PARAGRAPH:1]-- Tenorio

[PARAGRAPH:1]-- Tenorio

TEXT.English: "Sure, you could spend your gold on swords, but if they aren't in the right place they'll do you no good. You could buy a warehouse full of bolts, but they'll do you no good if you can't get enough to the archers on the battlefield. You might have scouts living on mountaintops all year round... and if they can't get back here quicker than your enemies they may as well stay there. All that gold, all for naught. Without a good horse it doesn't matter what you've got, or who you are. You're just a target waiting for a man with a lance."
TEXT.French: "Évidemment, vous pourriez dépenser votre or pour des épées, mais si elles ne sont pas au bon endroit, ça ne vaut pas tripette. Vous pourriez vous acheter un entrepôt entier de flèches et carreaux. Mais à quoi bon si vous n'arrivez pas à amener suffisamment d'archers jusqu'au champ de bataille. Vous pourriez bien disposer d'éclaireurs sur tous les pics montagneux tout l'année durant... mais s'ils n'arrivent pas à revenir plus vite que les ennemis qu'ils ont détecté, ils pourraient aussi bien rester posés là où ils sont. Tout cet or, pour RIEN ! Sans un bon cheval, peu importe ce que vous avez, ou qui vous êtes. Vous devenez une simple cible pour les javelots.".
TEXT.German: "Natürlich, ihr könntet Euer Geld üfr Schwerter ausgeben, aber wenn sie nicht dort sind, wo sie sein sollten, helfen sie rein gar nichts. Ihr könntet ein Lagerhaus voll mit Pfeilen und Bolzen kaufen, aber sie helfen rein gar nichts, wenn ihr sie nicht auf das Schlachtfeld bekommt, stimmts? Ihr könnt Eure Kundschafter das ganze Jahr über auf irgendwelchen Berggipfeln Ausschau halten lassen, doch wenn sie nicht schneller zurückkommen als die Feinde, können sie auch getrost dort bleiben. All das Gold, all das für nichts. Ohne ein gutes Pferd macht es keinen Unterschied, was man hat und wer man ist. Ihr seid einfach nur ein Ziel, das auf einen Mann mit Lanze wartet."
TEXT.Italian: "Certo, puoi sempre spendere l'oro per le spade, ma se non sono al posto giusto non ti serviranno a niente. Puoi compare un magazzino pieno di frecce, ma non serviranno a niente se non puoi portare abbastanza arcieri sul campo di battaglia. Potresti avere esploratori che vivono sulle cime delle montagne tutto l'anno... e se non possono tornare qui più velocemente dei tuoi nemici tanto vale che se ne restino li. Tutto quell'oro, buttato. Senza un buon cavallo non importa cosa hai, o chi sei. Sei solo un bersaglio in attesa di qualcuno con una lancia."

TEXT.English: Though a sharp blade and a sturdy shield can get you far in war, a massive wall and gate will stop any warrior dead in his tracks. Even the Jotnar will consider alternatives before attacking a walled city, as the defenders can use the elevation to their advantage.[NEWLINE]Thus, siege weaponry was invented. Catapults, ballistae, trebuchets, and cannons are suited to the arduous task of tearing down fortifications from a safe distance, and now ensure that siege warfare is much more complex and dangerous than it was before. However, these weapons are usually too burdensome to haul around in every battle.[NEWLINE]Siegesmiths change that: through fine-tuning parts and supplying specialized ammunition, the master siegesmith can turn siege engines into viable field weaponry. Even moreso for the Dwarves and the Mechanos, whose specialty in heavy artillery become a dangerous trait with the aid of a master siegesmith.

TEXT.Italian: Sebbene una lama affilata e uno scudo robusto ti porteranno lontano in guerra, un grande muro o cancello fermeranno qualsiasi guerriero sulla sua strada. Persino i Jotnar considererebbero le alternative prima di attaccare una città murata, visto che i difensori possiedono il vantaggio dell'altezza.[NEWLINE]Per questo le armi d'assedio furono inventate. Catapulte, ballistae, trabucchi, e cannoni sono adatti per l'arduo compito di distruggere le fortificazioni da una distanza di sicurezza, rendendo la guerra d'assedio molto più complessa e pericolosa di quanto era prima. Comunque, queste armi sono, di solito, troppo ingombranti per essere usate in ogni battaglia.[NEWLINE]I Fabbri d'assedio cambiano la situazione: attraverso particolari messe a punto e fornendo munizioni specializzate, il Mastro Fabbro d'assedio puo trasformare le armi d'assedio in accettabili artiglierie da campo. Ciò è ancor più valido per i Nani e i Mechanos, la cui specialità nell'artiglieria pesante diventa una caratteristica ancora più pericolosa con l'aiuto di un Mastro Fabbro d'assedio.

TEXT.English: Erebus is a world plunged into war; and where there is war, there will be a cadre of artisans knowledgeable in the arts of blacksmithing. Axes, swords, warhammers, spears, daggers, knives, lances, maces, platemail, chainmail, scalemail, skullcaps, helmets, and other such paraphenelia of combat line the walls of their shops.[NEWLINE]Indeed, war is a bloody business. But business is good; these blacksmiths may charge a heavy toll for their services, but there will always be a market for arms and armour in these troubled times.[NEWLINE]A smart general will see his soldiers resist savage blows from the enemy and return the favour with better results. From the savage Orcs to the zealous Bannor, a master blacksmith in their employ can turn the tide in the war against their hated enemy.

Asce, spade, martelli da guerra, lance, pugnali, coltelli, mazze, corazze di piastre, cotte di maglia, corazze di scaglie, elmi, e armamentario simile da combattimento ricoprono le pareti dei loro negozi.[NEWLINE]In effetti la guerra è un affare sanguinoso. Dai selvaggi Orchi ai zelanti Bannor, un Mastro Armaiolo al loro servizio può ribaltare la guerra contro i loro odiati nemici.

TEXT.English: [TAB]"I'm sure you've seen the play before, I hope the Elohim performance was enjoyable for you."[PARAGRAPH:1]A courtier refilled Ethne's wine glass. She and Dain were both seated at the end of a long table where noblemen, diplomats, actors and other artists were all starting a magnificent feast to celebrate the performance. Ethne smiled and spoke easily with the courtier, calling him by his first name and treating him as a friend, not a servant, as she did with everyone.[PARAGRAPH:1]"It was a beautiful play," Dain answered, "and although many perform the same play it is always interesting to see how each empire adds or changes the story to suit their tastes. But I must say that yours was the most beautiful, and without any of the illusions that we Amurites use in our shows."[PARAGRAPH:1]"The tailors struggled to compare to the beauty of the painters, the painters with our talented musicians, and our musicians with Sidney, our lovely lead. If only life were really that beautiful."[PARAGRAPH:1]"And as full of jealousy and heartlessness?" Dain quipped.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ethne's brow furrowed a bit at the comment. Dain instantly regretted it. He was here to firm up the diplomacy between their countries, something that would be required in the coming days. He needed the Elohim to go to war with the Infernal and had hoped to find an ally in the young queen, but now he worried that she was too compassionate to do what the world required, to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I saw a lot of hope in the story," Ethne responded after some thought, "eventually the tale ends well for everyone, especially for our humble heroine."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Perhaps. The story dates back to the Patrian empire, and it's interesting to see what has been changed in the Elohim version. It speaks well of the Elohim's gentle nature and kindness."[PARAGRAPH:1]"What has been changed from the original?" Ethne asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]The meal was served rich in butter and creams over vegetables and light on meat. Dain realized why Valledia hated these trips, as she was very fond of flanks of beef found in the Bannor and Hippus lands. She even enjoyed drinking and feasting with the Khazad, who Dain had little tolerance for.[PARAGRAPH:1]"For one," Dain said trying to capture a small potato on the end of his fork, "That wasn't her name. Her step-sisters made her work in the kitchen all day, including cleaning the chimney, which left her covered with black soot and cinders. And earned her the name they used to tease her."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Cinderella," Ethne said.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Right. And there was no carriage or fairy godmother. A tree grew on the grave of her mother, watered by her tears. Two birds in that tree brought her the dress and slippers. And at the end when the step-sisters tried to fit into the slipper one cut off her toe to fit into the slipper and the other cut off a portion of her heel."[PARAGRAPH:1]Ethne's eyes widened and others at the table quieted. The Elohim were wonderful hosts, but they weren't accustomed to talk of graves or mutilation at dinner. Dain thought again that he had gone too far and considered enchanting the pastries and causing them to dance around the table to draw attention from the conversation.[PARAGRAPH:1]"What does it say about the Patrians that they would tell the story so?" Ethne asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dain considered his answer carefully.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I think they loved the idea of the oppressed young maiden eventually being rewarded for her trials just as we do. But where we see a perfect solution that sets things right in the fairy godmother, they saw an option that was full of sorrow and hope in the birds. And where our story teaches that forgiveness and compassion transform everyone, even the wicked step-sisters are forgiven by the girl and go on to marry lords, the ancient version has them punished for their actions. The Patrians wanted to teach the audience that good people will earn their rewards, though they may have to suffer in the process. And that wicked people can not avoid their punishment indefinitely."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Which version to you like better?"[PARAGRAPH:1]By this point, though the rest of the table pretended to be absorbed in their soup, breads or examining their wine goblets they were all straining to hear the conversation. It was no longer about the play, though a few actors still thought it was, but about the war against the Infernal.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I wish that the current version could be true, but it is not that world that I am familiar with. I find it easier to laugh, cry and celebrate with the Cinderella in the Patrian story. And I would rather my children knew that there is sorrow in the world, and they can stand through it, rather than be surprised and unable to cope when they find it on their own."[PARAGRAPH:1]Ethne's eyes were so perfectly blue that it almost seemed they had based the color of their flag on them. "Do you know why I became queen?" Ethne asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No" Dain answered, "only that your people love you above all others."[PARAGRAPH:1]"It is because I have seen the disparity in the world, the hatred, the intolerance. I do not believe in a perfect world, but I want to make it so."[PARAGRAPH:1]"In that you have the full support of the Amurites." Dain answered. He had hoped that he was being subtle but Ethne was more clever than he gave her credit for.[PARAGRAPH:1]Courtiers began to clear the plates and the table fell back into talk more appropriate for dinner. Dain went down and personally congratulated Sidney, who was dressed in a beautiful blue and yellow dress, and the rest of the actors for their fine performance. They swooned in the compliments of the legendary archmage, and beamed when he offered to host their performance in Cevedes if they would visit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ethne talked with the visiting diplomats and other guests. She was genuinely happy for news of new births and marriages and gave sincere condolences with any news of loss or hardship. She gave her heart and complete attention to each person she met and it was impossible not to be amazed by her.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the guests began to leave she stood by Dain thanking each person for coming. When everyone but a few personal retainers was gone she asked Dain, "In your story, I assume the Amurites are Cinderella and the wicked step-sisters are the Infernal?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes," Dain answered.[PARAGRAPH:1]"And are the Elohim supposed to be the birds? Your supernatural ally against the Infernal?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes."[PARAGRAPH:1]She nodded, then thanked Dain for coming. They were to meet again in the morning to discuss treaties and she knew Dain would request that they declare war on the Infernal.[PARAGRAPH:1]As Dain walked away Ethne called after him, "What happened to the step-sisters at the end of the Patrian story?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Dain smiled grimly, "The birds pecked out their eyes."

Ethne chiese.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dain considerò attentamente la sua risposta.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Penso che amassero l'ide che la giovane ragazza oppressa fosse infine ricompensata per le sue sofferenza proprio come noi. TEXT.English: [TAB]If a wild Tiger is captured it can be taken to a city with a Carnival and added to the city as an attraction. This raises both the cultural and happiness effects of the Carnival.
TEXT.French: Si un Tigre est capturé, il peut être amené dans une ville avec un Carnaval et ajouté à la ville comme attraction. Cela augmente la production culturelle et le bonheur du Carnaval.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Wird ein wilder Tiger gefangen, kann er in eine Stadt mit einem Jahrmarkt gebracht werden und der Stadt als Attraktion zugefügt werden. Dadurch werden beide Effekte des Jahrmarktes (Kultur und Zufriedenheit) verstärkt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Se una Tigre viene catturata, e viene portata in una città con un Circo, può esssere unita alla città come attrazione. Fare ciò aumenta gli effetti del Circo riguardanti la Cultura e la Felicità.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Si un Tigre Salvaje es capturado, puede ser llevado a una ciudad con un Carnaval y ser añadido como una atracción para la ciudad. Esto aumenta los efectos de cultura y felicidad del Carnaval.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Bannor society men condemned to death for breaking oaths can be given temporary reprieve from execution if they serve in the military. They sacrifice their title, property, relationships and even their name. To everyone else it is as if they died on the gallows.[PARAGRAPH:1]These men are known as Forsworn Brothers, and no matter their valor or accomplishment their execution awaits them at the end of the war. Their only reward is the opportunity to die in battle instead of in a criminals' noose, and they pursue this goal with relentless devotion.

Sie geben ihre Titel, ihren Besitz, ihre Beziehungen und sogar ihren Namen auf. Für alle anderen ist es so, als ob sie am Galgen gestorben wären.[PARAGRAPH:1]Diese Männer sind als Brüder des Eidbruchs bekannt und egal, wieviel Heldenmut oder Einsatz sie zeigen, am Ende des Krieges erwartet sie ihre Hinrichtung. Ihre einziger Lohn ist die Gelegenheit, im Kampf statt durch den Strang zu sterben, und sie verfolgen dieses Ziel mit unbarmherziger Hingabe.

Rinunciano al loro titolo, alle loro prorpietà, alle loro relazioni e persino al loro nome. Per tutti gli altri è come se morisserò sulla forca.[PARAGRAPH:1]Queste persone sono conosciute come Fratelli Rinnegati, e non importa il loro valore o i loro risultati la loro esecuzione li attende alla fine della guerra. La loro unica ricompensa è la possibilità di morire in battaglia invece che con il cappio, e perseguono questo obiettivo con un'implacabile dedizione.

TEXT.English: A Hunter's Hall is a place for the most experienced hunters of both animals and men to sit, reminisce, and teach the next generation.
TEXT.French: A Hunter's Hall is a place for the most experienced hunters of both animals and men to sit, reminisce, and teach the next generation.
